head.title: The Bensonhurst Case; Bensonhurst: Key Events

hedline.hl1: The Bensonhurst Case; Bensonhurst: Key Events

block.p: LEAD: Aug. 23, 1989: A crowd of some 40 whites attacks four black youths in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn. Yusuf K. Hawkins, 16 years old, is slain by shots from a semi-automatic pistol.

Aug. 23, 1989: A crowd of some 40 whites attacks four black youths in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn. Yusuf K. Hawkins, 16 years old, is slain by shots from a semi-automatic pistol.
Aug. 27:Five white youths are arraigned in Criminal Court in Brooklyn on charges stemming from the murder. Among them is Keith Mondello, identified as an organizer of the attack.

Aug. 30:Joseph Fama, 18, a fugitive since the day of the Hawkins killing, gives himself up to the police in Oneonta, N.Y. Some 30 police officers and demonstrators are injured as 7,500 people participate in a ''Day of Outrage'' march in Brooklyn to protest Mr. Hawkins's killing.
Sept. 1:Mr. Fama pleads not guilty in Criminal Court to two counts of murder and is ordered held without bail.
Sept. 3:A protest march through Bensonhurst proceeds without incident, except for taunts. Some 300 marchers are protected by 400 police officers.
Sept. 6:Mr. Fama is indicted on two counts of second-degree murder.
January 1990:John S. Vento, a witness to the killing of Mr. Hawkins, disappears.
March 7: Mr. Vento surrenders to the police in Dayton, Ohio, and is returned to New York.
March 12:Mr. Vento decides not to testify and is charged with second-degree murder.
April 16:The trial of Mr. Fama and Mr. Mondello opens in Brooklyn with separate juries.
April 20:A prisoner testifies that Mr. Fama acknowledged during a jailhouse conversation in March that he killed Mr. Hawkins.
May 17:Mr. Fama is convicted of second-degree murder.
